page.title: 09Llandudno: Historical (1)
page.content: {Named after the church (Llan) of St. {Tudno,}an ancient Christian saint, {Llandudno}developed into its present-day form as a seaside resort in a short space of time. Prior to 1848, it had been a village of approx 1,000 inhabitants, situated on the lower slopes of the Gt. Orme. The principal industries were{copper {mining,}farming and fishing. At their height, the copper mines employed 300 to 400 men and the area became known as the{'Welsh California'. The resort had its origins in the {Enclosure Act of 1843,}most of the common land being apportioned to the Hon.Edward Mostyn. The present town shows the influence of{careful plan- {ning}in its wide streets, avenues and the promenade development following the sweep of the shoreline between the Great Orme and the Little Orme.
